title: Sri Lanka rupee remains at 330/340 to TT dollar, bill yields ease
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s commercial banks quoted the rupee at 330/340 for telegraphic transfers on April 22, remaining flat throughout the week, while the interbank spot was mostly inactive, market participants said.
The central bank’s indicative spot was quoted at 334 rupees against the US dollar on Friday.
On Friday, the central bank’s telegraphic transfer rate was 327.5/339.99 against the US dollar, remaining the same as Thursday.
In bond markets, completely inactive due to the ongoing uncertainities in the country, market participants said.
Dealers said there were no active quotes for bond maturities.
However, the three-month bill was quoted at 20.25/20.75 percent, easing from 20.30/21 percent on Thursday.
The six months bill was quoted at 21.50/22.50 on Friday while
one-year bill was quoted at 22.50/23.50 percent on Friday, down from 22.30/23 percent.
Bill yields started easing following the weekly bill auction as interest in Treasuries was kindled.
At the weekly bills auction, although the debt office only sold 45.15 billion out of the offered 97.5 billion rupees, yields rose across all maturities.

Bond markets expect more money to low in at higher rates, helping fund the deficit and reduce money printing. Sri Lanka’s rupee is under severe pressure due to earlier money printing and an existing surrender rule.
But a hike in the policy rate and adjusting market rates will reduce domestic private credit and demand, slowing economic activity and imports. (Colombo/Apr22/2022)
